intro: Syringodea saxatilis, commonly known as the rock syringa, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to rocky habitats in Europe. It belongs to the family Polygalaceae and is characterized by its slender, upright stems and clusters of small, fragrant flowers. The plant produces white to pale pink flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and often have a slightly hairy texture. Syringodea saxatilis is adapted to grow in well-drained soils and is often found in limestone or sandstone environments.
